docs.lead_paragraph: A final House vote this Thursday amounts to a Republican bet that voters will reward the party for its tough-love priorities on spending.

headline.main: House Bill Offers Aid Cuts to Save Military Spending
headline.print_headline: House Bill Offers Aid Cuts To Save Military Spending

docs.abstract: Republican-led House will lay bare the choice between social programs and Pentagon spending when it votes on budget legislation to slice $261 billion from social service programs over the next decade to stave off more than $50 billion in military spending cuts scheduled to take effect in 2013.
docs.snippet: A final House vote this Thursday amounts to a Republican bet that voters will reward the party for its tough-love priorities on spending.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal court on Monday reversed its demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system.

headline.main: California: Call for Veterans Agency Fixes Is Reversed
headline.print_headline: California: Call For Veterans Agency Fixes Is Reversed

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court reverses earlier demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system, saying that any such changes need to be ordered by Congress or the president.
docs.snippet: A federal court on Monday reversed its demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: The study compared 25 rural Rwandan clinics that offered AIDS treatment with 25 similar clinics that did not.

headline.seo: AIDS Funds Don’t Detract From Rwanda’s Other Health Goals
headline.main: Flood of Donations to Fight AIDS Appears Not to Detract From Other Health Issues
headline.print_headline: Rwanda: Flood of Donations to Fight AIDS Appears Not to Detract From Other Health Issues

docs.abstract: Study by Brandeis University health policy analysts in The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene finds that large donations toward fighting AIDS in poor African countries do not necessarily detract from addressing other local medical problems.
docs.snippet: The study compared 25 rural Rwandan clinics that offered AIDS treatment with 25 similar clinics that did not.

keywords.value: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While Occupy Wall Street and the Buffett tax focus on the top 1 percent, many more Americans should expect to pay additional taxes regardless of who becomes our next president. When the economy recovers sufficiently, Congress must consider eliminating the 2001 and 2003 Bush tax cuts for most taxpayers and other tax breaks.

headline.main: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Call for Tax Reform

docs.snippet: A former tax lawyer calls for eliminating the Bush tax cuts for all and ending most tax breaks. Readers are invited to respond.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just how broken is our health care system? Dr. Otis Webb Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society, paints a grim picture in his new book, ''How We Do Harm: A Doctor Breaks Ranks About Being Sick in America'' (St. Martin's Press). If the title alone doesn't clue you in, the reader quickly discovers that Dr. Brawley is determined to make everyone as uncomfortable as possible about the flaws, inconsistencies and inequities that are rampant in American medical care. The book, written with Paul Goldberg, a journalist, begins with a frightening tale of a poor woman who for so long went untreated for breast cancer that her whole breast falls off at home.

headline.main: Plenty of Blame in a Health System 'Designed to Fail'

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column interview with Dr Otis Webb Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society and author of book How We Do Harm: A Doctor Breaks Ranks About Being Sick in America. Photo (M)t
